# ggplot2 `r emo::ji("heart")` `r emo::ji("penguin")`

## ggplot2 $\in$ tidyverse

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="30%"}
![](images/ggplot2-part-of-tidyverse.png)
:::

::: {.column width="70%"}
- **ggplot2** is tidyverse's data visualization package 

. . .

- Structure of the code for plots can be summarized as

```{r}
#| eval: false
#| code-line-numbers: "|1|2|3|5|6"

ggplot(
  data = [dataset], 
  mapping = aes(x = [x-variable], y = [y-variable])
  ) +
  geom_xxx() +
  other options
```
:::

::::

## Data: Palmer Penguins

Measurements for penguin species, island in Palmer Archipelago, size (flipper length, body mass, bill dimensions), and sex.

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="30%"}
![](images/penguins.png)
:::

::: {.column width="70%"}
::: small
```{r}
#| code-line-numbers: "|1-2|4"
#| output-location: fragment

library(tidyverse)
library(palmerpenguins)

glimpse(penguins)
```
:::
:::

::::

## Goal

::: {.panel-tabset}

### Plot

```{r}
#| ref.label: penguins-goal
#| echo: false
#| warning: false
#| out-width: 100%
#| fig-width: 8
#| fig-asp: 0.5
```

### Code

```{r}
#| label: penguins-goal
#| fig-show: hide

ggplot(
  data = penguins, 
  mapping = aes(x = bill_depth_mm, y = bill_length_mm, color = species)
  ) +
  geom_point() +
  labs(
    title = "Bill depth and length",
    subtitle = "Dimensions for Adelie, Chinstrap, and Gentoo Penguins",
    x = "Bill depth (mm)", y = "Bill length (mm)",
    color = "Species",
    caption = "Source: Palmer Station LTER / palmerpenguins package"
  ) +
  scale_color_viridis_d()
```

:::

### Narrative

Start with the `penguins` data frame,
map bill depth to the x-axis
and map bill length to the y-axis. 

Represent each observation with a point
and map species to the color of each point.

Title the plot "Bill depth and length", 
add the subtitle "Dimensions for Adelie, Chinstrap, and Gentoo Penguins", 
label the x and y axes as "Bill depth (mm)" and "Bill length (mm)", respectively,
label the legend "Species", 
and add a caption for the data source.

Finally, use a discrete color scale that is designed to be perceived by viewers with common forms of color blindness.

:::

## Argument names

::: {.callout-tip}
You can omit the names of first two arguments when building plots with `ggplot()`.
:::

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="50%"}
```{r}
#| label: named-args
#| fig-show: hide
#| code-line-numbers: "|2-7"

ggplot(
  data = penguins,
  mapping = aes(
    x = bill_depth_mm,
    y = bill_length_mm,
    color = species
    )
  ) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_color_viridis_d()
```
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
```{r}
#| label: not-named-args
#| fig-show: hide
#| code-line-numbers: "|2-7"

ggplot(
  penguins,
  aes(
    x = bill_depth_mm,
    y = bill_length_mm,
    color = species
    )
  ) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_color_viridis_d()
```
:::
